awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Non-precious metal substitution into hydrogenation metal alloy catalysts deposited onto redox active supports for facile nitrate destruction in drinking water
awd_abstract_narration:
United States companies spend almost $3 billion a year buying and making reduction catalysts to help create fuel, fertilizers, and medicines. Given this investment and proven success, it is perhaps surprising that these catalysts are not used to produce potable drinking water. Instead, current drinking water treatment methods are costly and have potential to harm the environment. The main reason reduction catalysts are not used to clean water is because they are made from precious metals that also have a high cost, and water is a low value product.  The research goal of this work is to advance the science of water treatment by replacing precious metals with inexpensive metal reduction catalysts to achieve treatment goals at the lowest cost and with the least harm to the environment. The catalysts will be used to treat nitrate, the most common groundwater pollutant in the world that results primarily from agricultural fertilizer.  Student researchers will be trained to become future leaders in this technology, so they can train others to design more effective water treatment plants.

The primary goal of the proposed work is to advance the science of supported metal-alloy catalysis for the treatment of the ubiquitous water pollutant nitrate. The specific objectives are to 1) develop new metal alloy nanoparticle catalysts with markedly higher catalytic activity for nitrate reduction; 2) identify electronically active supports that enhance catalytic activity and stability of alloy metal nanoparticles for water treatment; and 3) evaluate the environmental impacts and costs of the new catalysts using life cycle assessment. To address these objectives, a suite of platinum group metal-based alloy nanoparticles with lattice substituted semi- and non-precious metals will be synthesized using a novel microwave-assisted method. The catalysts will be supported on a series of redox active supports and characterized using advanced microscopic/spectroscopic techniques. The new catalysts will be evaluated with/without amended indium for nitrate and nitrite reduction kinetics, and selectivity for ammonia.  The results will be compared to catalyst properties and interpreted with density functional theory to identify controlling mechanisms. Long-term catalyst stability will be evaluated under realistic water treatment conditions, and the results used to perform economic and environmental life cycle assessments.  The proposed work will result in new fundamental knowledge regarding 1) the effects of hydrogenation-inactive metals on catalysis; 2) the influence of redox active supports on alloy metal alloy nanoparticle activity and stability; and 3) a quantitative assessment of the effects of metal alloys on cost and sustainability of catalytic treatment of drinking water.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we advanced the development of new water treatment technologies to destroy pollutants in drinking water sources.  The new water treatment technologies rely on a reaction that combines either hydrogen gas or electricity to destroy pollutants, and a catalyst to speed the reaction.  Most people are familiar with catalysts because of the catalytic converter in their car, which speeds the destruction of pollutant that exit the car tail pipe.  Catalysts for water treatment work the same way.  The catalysts we focused on were palladium, ruthenium, gold, silver, cobalt, iridium, indium, and copper metals, in some cases randomly mixed together into alloys in efforts to either decrease overall costs or improve ability to destroy pollutants.  We used customized methods to create single metal and alloy catalysts as nanoparticles, which are very small particles comprised of hundreds to thousands of atoms.  Using nanoparticles instead of larger particles reduced the amount of metals we needed to get a desired amount of reaction.  Ideally, we wanted our nanoparticles to be made from copper or similar inexpensive metals, instead of expensive precious metals like palladium and gold.  Therefore, part of our work involved trying to find inexpensive catalysts that destroyed pollutants as fast and reliable as possible and at a minimum cost. 

The pollutants we focused on were bromate, nitrite, and nitrate.  Bromate is inadvertently created from bromide during water treatment, when the oxidant ozone is used to destroy pathogenic bacteria.  The bromate is produced is small quantities, but is still toxic and a concern.  Nitrite and nitrate are created from fertilizer runoff from farm fields.  They get into water supplies and must be removed during the drinking water treatment process.  Because of the widespread use of fertilizers, nitrite and nitrate are the most common groundwater contaminants in the world, and seasonal surface water pollutants.  Nitrate and nitrite can be toxic, and have been linked to various forms of cancer.  The water treatment plants that treat for bromate, nitrite, and nitrate often use ion exchange resins, but this treatment technology only captures these pollutants in a concentrated form and does not destroy them. 

There are several major findings from our work that are summarized in six peer-reviewed publications.  We determined that we could mix expensive palladium with inexpensive silver and create nanoparticle alloy catalysts, and we could get faster nitrite destruction with the cheaper catalyst with silver substituted for palladium.  We also found that almost all of the nitrite destroyed yielded harmless dinitrogen gas, so no further water treatment was required.  We determined that we could mix small amounts of palladium with ruthenium and create nanoparticle alloys.  The additional of ruthenium allowed us to convert nitrate to ammonia, and then ammonia could be recovered for reuse as a fertilizer or chemical feedstock.  We developed a novel flow-through reactor that uses electricity instead of hydrogen gas to destroy nitrate, and also developed a novel activated carbon cloth electrode decorated with small amounts of catalysts.  We evaluated palladium, copper, cobalt, iridium, and indium metals, and mixtures of these, as catalysts, and found the best combination that resulted in the fastest, most energy efficient, and most robust nitrate destruction was copper with trace amounts of palladium added.  We determined using the copper-palladium on carbon cloth electrode that mostly ammonia was produced as the final product, and ammonia could be recovered such that electrochemical treatment was similar in cost to nitrate treatment using ion exchange resins.

We then shifted our attention to bromate destruction, and evaluated a suite of different palladium, copper, and silver metals, and their mixtures, as catalyst for bromate destruction.   We determined that palladium-copper or palladium-silver nanoparticle alloy catalysts resulted in the fastest bromate destruction.  We also determined that we could synthesize these catalysts using a method called incipient wetness, that is scalable in commercial production.  We then used our flow through electrochemical reactor to evaluate its suitability for bromate destruction.  We evaluated several different catalysts metals (palladium, ruthenium, copper) on the carbon cloth electrode for bromate destruction, and determined that palladium alone provided very fast and reliable destruction.  We also found that the only end product was relatively harmless bromide. 

Overall, our results advanced catalytic treatment technologies for nitrate, nitrite, and bromate.  They determined that both hydrogen-based and electrochemical approaches are cost competitive, and that they show sufficient promise such that larger scale evaluation in pilot systems are needed to advance to the next step.
